metadata.title: What are AI Models? | AI Models Explained
metadata.author: Glide

transcript: We use AI for so much, for writing emails, summarizing reports, and even recommending what we eat. But behind all that magic, there is something called an AI model. If you ever wonder what models like GPD4, Claude, or Gymnite actually do, and how to choose the right one, this video is for you. And if you're thinking about building your own AI tools like smart assistant, a content generator, or a lead scoring app, I'll show you how platforms like Thrive actually do that without writing a single line of code. Let's dive in. An AM model is like a digital brain trains of ton of information. You ask it a question or give it a task and it gives you a response. That could be a piece of writing, a summary, an image, code, anything. But not all AI models are the same. Each one has different strengths, weaknesses, and ideal uses. Let's say you are building something with AI, like a customer support bot or a tool to organize your sales lead. Do you want it to answer fast, handle long documents, be great at writing? Different goals call for different models. Start by asking, what do I need this AI to do? Does it need to be fast, accurate, or cost effective? Am I working with private or sensitive data? Do I need deep reasoning or just a quick short answers? Once you're clear on what you need, choosing the right model becomes much easier. Let's take a look at some of the most widely used AI models today and what they are each designed to do. This will help you understand the range of capabilities out there and how different models are built with different goals in mind. GBD4 by OpenAI, a general purpose model built for deep reasoning, writing and complex tasks. Often used for research, coding, or anything that needs accuracy and context. Three, bionthropic. This is great for summarizing documents and maintaining a helpful balanced tone. Popular in customer support and document heavy use cases. Gemini 1.5 by Google. A multimodel model, meaning it can understand images, video, and text all at once. Used in tools that combine visual and written inputs. Mistral by Mistl AI. Open- source, lightweight, and designed for speed and efficiency. Often chosen for the smaller apps or when cost is a factor. Deepseek by DeepSci. Designed for technical tasks like math and code. It's a good fit for tools that requisi built for real-time responses using current web data. still evolving, but aim at use cases where up to the info is key. These are just a few examples of the most talked about models right now. Each one is optimized for different goals. So, understanding what you need is key before picking one. There's a big difference between just using AI and actually integrating it with into a tool or workflow. If you are building a software for your team or business, picking the right model is a big deal. Do you go with GBD4, HUD, Mistral? Which one is faster, safer, cheaper? That's where Glide comes in. Glide automatically selects the best model for your use case, whether it's summarizing text, classifying data, or generating content and connect you to the enterprisegrade version that's far secure and your data is never used for training. Once the model is set, you can build apps that put the AI power directly in your user's hands, whether it's internal teams or customers. Now, this means smarter inputs, a system workflows, or dynamic features, all inside your own custom software. No code required. So to recap, a models are the brains behind most modern tools. Each one has unique strengths. Pick based on what you need. And if you want to build with AI without being a developer, BL makes it possible. Did this help? Hit a like and subscribe for more videos about AI automation and building smart businesses. Got questions? Drop them in the comments. I'll read them all. I'll see you in the next one. key_facts: AI models act as digital brains trained on vast amounts of information.
An AI model responds to questions or tasks with outputs like writing, summaries, images, or code.
Not all AI models are the same; each has distinct strengths, weaknesses, and ideal use cases.
Choosing an AI model depends on specific needs such as speed, accuracy, cost, or data sensitivity.
GPT-4 by OpenAI is designed for deep reasoning, writing, and complex tasks.
GPT-4 is commonly used for research, coding, and applications requiring high accuracy and context.
Claude by Anthropic excels at summarizing documents and maintaining a helpful, balanced tone.
Claude is popular in customer support and document-heavy workflows.
Gemini 1.5 by Google is a multimodal model capable of processing text, images, and video simultaneously.
Gemini 1.5 is used in tools that combine visual and written inputs.
Mistral by Mistral AI is open-source, lightweight, and optimized for speed and efficiency.
Mistral is often selected for smaller applications or when cost is a primary concern.
Deepseek by DeepSeek is designed for technical tasks such as math and code generation.
Deepseek is suited for real-time responses using current web data.
Deepseek is still evolving but targets use cases where up-to-date information is critical.
There is a distinction between simply using AI and integrating it into a tool or workflow.
Building business software with AI requires careful model selection based on performance and security needs.
Glide automatically selects the best AI model for a given use case.
Glide connects users to enterprise-grade versions of models with enhanced security.
Glide ensures user data is never used for training any model.
With Glide, users can build custom apps that embed AI directly into workflows.
No coding is required to build AI-powered applications using Glide.
AI models serve as the core intelligence behind most modern digital tools.
Understanding your requirements is essential before selecting an AI model.
The choice of model impacts performance, safety, and cost in AI-driven applications.
key_opinions: Picking the right AI model makes a significant difference when building business tools.
GPT-4 is ideal for complex, context-sensitive tasks requiring deep reasoning.
Claudeâ€™s balanced tone makes it particularly suitable for customer-facing applications.
Multimodal models like Gemini 1.5 enable richer interactions across media types.
Lightweight models like Mistral offer better value for small-scale or budget-conscious projects.
Deepseek is well-suited for dynamic, real-time technical applications.
Glide simplifies AI integration by automating model selection and deployment.
Enterprise-grade models via Glide provide stronger data privacy guarantees.
No-code platforms like Glide empower non-developers to build intelligent applications.
The future of business tools lies in embedding AI directly into custom software.
key_datapoints: GPT-4 is used for research, coding, and high-context tasks.
Claude is frequently used in customer support and document-heavy environments.
Gemini 1.5 supports text, image, and video input simultaneously.
Mistral is open-source and optimized for speed and low resource usage.
Deepseek is designed for real-time responses using live web data.
Glide offers enterprise-grade model access with no data retention for training.
AI models can generate text, summaries, code, images, and more.
Model selection affects response speed, accuracy, and cost-efficiency.
Glide enables app creation without writing a single line of code.
User data remains private and is not used for model training in Glide.
AI integration improves system workflows and dynamic feature delivery.
Custom AI apps can be built for internal teams or external customers.
Multiple AI models are available for different application scenarios.
Real-time data responsiveness is a key feature of Deepseek.
Open-source models like Mistral reduce dependency on proprietary systems.
